Expect your career to stagnate if you take a BI position here. This type of role is best taken at the end of your career, especially if the Pros listed are appealing to you.

To recap: Ball places no value on collected data, it's only a cost to be lowered. If they are desperate for an occasional operational metric, that's why they have BI roles, otherwise you'll be bored out of your mind. Run away!

advice: Be more proactive about listening to suggestions from the staff, make improvements to the IT department (literally no one likes having to contact IT) and be receptive to change. This company is too "old fashioned" in their ethic, and it needs to be brought to current industry standards. There's a reason why talent is leaving, and it's because everything is stuck 20 years in the past (improve your diversity by hiring young talent that is current on industry standards and trends).
cons: Departments are severely understaffed to the point everyone works more than 40 hours a week. Upper D-level management is not willing to listen to suggestions for improvement. They are severely lacking in their IT department, refusing the use of new software or tools that would be nice to have (hard no, even on free applications). The "technology" that is used is so outdated, and the reliance on complicated Excel sheets instead of business intelligence tools is absurd. Some of the management I've worked with aren't looking to try and make improvements, declining any suggestions. Communication with upper management is challenging, given their packed schedules - they don't return emails or calls but expect work to be done (and work that requires their input). Departments don't interact with each other, and communication between them gets messy; you often need to make several attempts to get an answer and there is no direct point of contact. Outlined objectives are rarely worked on, leaving departments to be reactive instead of proactive, always "putting out the fire" instead of improving work flow and methods. Despite the generous vacation time, it's hard to actually book more than 1-2 days off at a time because there's so much work to be done and one missed day causes huge impacts and delays. Management doesn't seem to like someone calling in sick, even in an emergency (with a medical note). Everything just moves very slowly, even though everyone is busy (probably because the delays in senior management). There are also SO many meetings that prevent people from getting work done - I manage several calendars and people have been booked for 30+ hours of meetings in one week, leading to "mandatory" overtime as people have work that needs to get done.
pros: Decent pay, benefits started immediately, nice bonus, generous vacation time. Overall, the culture is good, and people are knowledgeable in their assigned roles. There are a lot of good, hard working people, but the cons outweigh the pros.
title: Good culture, but horrid environment

advice: Review HR exit interviews -scuttlebutt is they are stuck in a folder and never looked at.   Ask HR about the feedback they're getting - and tell them you want the truth.  Ask for information from line employees.  Review departmental managements' claims.  Dig into the details.  Look at department trends - turnover, promotions, organization (regular reorganizing, levels of management, direct report numbers).  Don't believe the spin.
cons:
Long-term employment can engender the "we've always done it this way" mentality.  Change is difficult.  
Management deficiencies are not addressed in a timely manner.  Departments founder while senior management looks the other way.
Growth by acquisition with no defined process for integration has made Ball a corporation of individual entities.  There are no common processes, which causes inefficiencies and engenders errors.  Each manufacturing plant works differently.  None wants to change.  There is no standardization, which means there is no common ground and no basis for comparison.  Power plays abound.
Old school reigns.  Technology is resisted.  Attracting and retaining younger, motivated employees is a problem
pros:
Many people are long-term (career) employees.  They know the company, they are committed to doing a good job, and they work hard.  They care about the company and its successes.  This is one of the few remaining places where many people work their entire careers.
Ball provides very good benefits for their employees.  It emphasizes health and savings for the future.  Health care options are reasonable and broad enough to accommodate different needs.  Ball pays a significant part of the costs.
Ball still provides a pension plan in addition to 401(k), including match.  There is no fixed number of sick days, and my experience is that people do not abuse this.  After 5 consecutive days, short-term disability kicks in.
title: If it sounds too good to be true, it probably is.
